info.headline: Flood Advisory issued May 15 at 12:39PM MDT until further notice by NWS GrandJunction
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Grand Junction has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Colorado... Gunnison River at Delta affecting Delta County. .The combination of warm, spring temperatures and the potential for periods of heavy rain falling on a deep snowpack would lead to an increase in runoff from snowmelt. Flows in rivers will increase quickly and are expected to reach critical levels by the end of the week. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt is expected. * WHERE...Gunnison River at Delta. * WHEN...From this afternoon until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, water reaches the base of the berms in the Four Seasons River Inn RV Park and Riverwood Mobile Home Park, water nears the top of the berm separating Confluence Park from the Gunnison River, and the right river bank across from Confluence Park may be flooded. At 10.5 feet, the river gage site becomes flooded. At 11.0 feet, flooding of low-lying agricultural land is possible, while portions of Confluence Park in the vicinity of the Gunnison River is expected to flood. In addition, some hiking trails near the confluence with the Uncompahgre River may become inundated by water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:15 AM MDT Monday the stage was 7.7 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate below flood stage with a maximum value of 10.7 feet Saturday afternoon. - Action stage is 9.5 feet. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (12 pm MDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Tue Wed Thu Gunnison River Delta 12.0 7.7 Mon 11 am MD 8.3 9.1 9.8 &&
info.instruction: If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternative route. If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a warning. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
